01.text: A new part of the story begins here and continues through the end of the chapter. The writer tells about Herod's attempt to kill the new King of the Jews.
"the town of Bethlehem in the province of Judea" (UDB)

01.ref: in the days of Herod the king

01.text: This refers to Herod the Great.
"from a country far east of Judea"

01.ref: Where is he who was born King of the Jews?
01.text: The men knew from studying the stars that the one who would become king had been born. They were trying to learn where he was. AT: "A baby who will become the king of the Jews has been born. Where is he?"
They were not saying that the baby was the rightful owner of the star. AT: "the star that tells about him" or "the star that is associated with his birth"
"as it came up in the east" or "while we were in our country"

Possible meanings are 1) they intended to worship the baby as divine, or 2) they wanted to honor him as a human king. If your language has a word that includes both meanings, you should consider using it here.
"he was worried." Herod was worried that this baby would replace him as king.

Here "Jerusalem" refers to the people. Also, "all" means "many." Matthew is exaggerating to emphasize how many people were worried. AT: "many of the people in Jerusalem" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy|Metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole|Hyperbole]])

04.text: In verse 6, the chief priests and scribes of the people quote the prophet Micah to show that the Christ would be born in Bethlehem.
"In the town of Bethlehem in the province of Judea"

04.ref: this is what was written by the prophet
04.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "this is what the prophet wrote long ago" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

04.ref: you, Bethlehem, ... are not the least among the leaders of Judah
04.text: Micah was speaking to the people of Bethlehem as if they were with him but they were not. Also, "are not the least" can be translated with a positive phrase. AT: "you, people of Bethlehem, ... your town is among the most important towns in Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

04.ref: who will shepherd my people Israel
04.text: Micah speaks of this ruler as a shepherd. This means he will lead and care for the people. AT: "who will lead my people Israel as a shepherd leads his sheep" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

07.ref: Herod secretly called the learned men
07.text: This means that Herod talked to the learned men without other people knowing.

07.ref: to ask them exactly what time the star had appeared
07.text: This can be translated as a direct quotation. AT: "and he asked them, 'When exactly did this star appear?'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

07.ref: what time the star had appeared
07.text: It is implied that the learned men told him when the star appeared. AT: "what time the star had appeared. The learned men told Herod when the star first appeared" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "word" is a metonym for "message" or "new." AT: "let me know" or "tell me" or "report back to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Translate this as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:02:01|2:2]].

09.ref: they had seen in the east
09.text: "they had seen come up in the east" or "they had seen in their country"
"the place where the young child was staying"

11.text: Here the scene shifts to the house where Mary, Joseph, and the young Jesus were living.
Here "treasures" refers to the boxes or bags they used to carry their treasures. AT: "the containers that held their treasures" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Afterwards, God warned the learned men." God knew that Herod wanted to harm the child.
This can be translated as a direct quotation. AT: "saying, 'Do not go back to King Herod'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

13.text: In verse 15, the writer quotes the prophet Hosea to show that the Christ would spend time in Egypt.

13.ref: appeared to Joseph in a dream
13.text: "came to Joseph while he was dreaming"

13.ref: Get up, take ... flee ... Remain ... you
13.text: God is speaking to Joseph, so these should all be singular forms. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "until I tell you it is safe to come back" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "I" refers to God. The angel is speaking for God.
It is implied that Joseph, Mary, and Jesus remained in Egypt. AT: "They remained" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Herod does not die until [[:en:bible:notes:mat:02:19|2:19]]. This statement describes the length of their stay in Egypt, and it does not say that Herod died at this time.

13.ref: Out of Egypt I have called my son
13.text: "I have called my son out of Egypt"
In Hosea this refers to the people of Israel. Matthew quoted it to say that this was true of God's Son, Jesus. Translate it using a word for son that could refer to the only son or the first son.

16.text: Here the scene shifts back to Herod and tells what he did when he learned that the learned men had deceived him.
These events happen before Herod's death, which the writer mentioned in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:02:13|2:15]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_events]])

16.ref: he had been mocked by the learned men
16.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the learned men had embarrassed him by tricking him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

16.ref: He sent and killed all the male children
16.text: Herod did not kill the children himself. AT: "He gave orders for his soldiers to kill all the boys" or "He sent soldiers there to kill all the boy babies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

17.text: The writer quotes the prophet Jeremiah to show that the death of all of the male children in the region of Bethlehem was according to scripture.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "This fulfilled" or "Herod's actions fulfilled" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

17.ref: what had been spoken through Jeremiah the prophet
17.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "what the Lord spoke long ago through the prophet Jeremiah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

17.ref: A voice was heard ... they were no more
17.text: Matthew is quoting the prophet Jeremiah.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "People heard a voice" or "There was a loud sound" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Rachel lived many years before this time. This prophecy shows Rachel, who has died, weeping for her descendants.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "no one could comfort her" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"because the children were gone and would never return." Here "were no more" is a mild way of saying they are dead. AT: "because they were dead" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

19.text: Here the scene shifts to Egypt, where Joseph, Mary, and the young Jesus are living.
This marks the beginning of another event in the larger story. It may involve different people than the previous events. Your language may have a way of doing this.

19.ref: those who sought the child's life
19.text: Here "sought the child's life" is a way of saying they wanted to kill the child. "AT: "those who were looking for the child in order to kill him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
This refers to King Herod and his advisors.

22.text: This is the end of the part of the story that began in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:02:01|2:1]] about Herod's attempt to kill the new King of the Jews.
This is the name of Herod's son. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

22.ref: what had been spoken through the prophets
22.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "what the Lord spoke long ago through the prophets" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

22.ref: he would be called a Nazarene
22.text: Here "he" refers to Jesus. The prophets before the time of Jesus would have referred to him as the Messiah or the Christ. AT: "people would say that the Christ is a Nazarene" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
